paragraph.heading: 1Editor Features
paragraph.paragraph:
The editor window pane is used to edit the source code of the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>classes in your Eiffel project. To load a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class into the editor you must double-click on the particular
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class you wish to edit in either the
../30_Class_View/index.xml Class View or
../20_Solution_Explorer/index.xml Solution Explorer . To edit more than one
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class simultaneously just double-click another
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class and this will appear in a separate tab in the editor pane. The screenshot below illustrates a project with 3
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>classes opened for editing in the editor window pane.

Once inside the editor you can edit the source code as you would any Eiffel
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class ; add or remove class
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex attributes>attributes ,
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features ,
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel inheritance>inheritance clauses,
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel precondition>preconditions and
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel postcondition>postconditions or any other feature provided by the Eiffel Language.
The editor provides a number of useful features for the developer:

list.item: Syntax coloring: Eiffel syntax keywords (such as create, is, do, end) are automatically colored in the text to make it easier to read and find different parts of the textmore quickly. Also, syntax elements such brackets and curly braces are colored, making it much easier to spot syntax errors and correct them quickly.

Member completion: provides a context-sensitive list of
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features available to the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class being edited. For example, if you are have a STRING variable 'a_string' and wish to clear the contents of theSTRING at a certain point in your code, when you type 'a_string' in the editor and then press the '.' to denote a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>feature call on 'a_string' the list will appear displaying all available
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features from 'a_string' to the current class. This is extremely useful as it gives a quick overview of the available
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features and automatically completes the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>feature name in the text once selected. This feature only works if the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>feature of the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class being edited is complied into the system, so to take full advantage it is best to compile your system as soon asyou add new
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>features .

Parameter information: when using a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>feature from a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel class>class which takes
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel argument>argument parameters the parameter information is displayed automatically when the opening bracket is enteredinto the text. This is similar to member completion and gives quick and immediate details about the argument parameters a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel feature>feature requires and the return type of the, if any.
